titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to John H. Tait, 1915
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Letter includes affixed 1915 route card, which establishes the year, August or earlier. John H. Tait (c1873-1940) was with the 1st U.S. Volunteer Cavalry (Roosevelt Rough Riders) during the Spanish American War May 1- September 30, 1898; Tait is listed as a Roosevelt Rough Rider in the 1899 and 1902 BBWW route books but does not appear in the 1900 route book. From BB names list: Frank L. Dutton and Samuel F. Dutton: WFC acquaintances and pallbearers at Cody's funeral in 1917. Frederick Bailey Hutchinson (c.1872-1944) was James A. Bailey's nephew and BBWW manager for the last European tour. John Brisben Walker (1847-1931) purchased Cosmopolitan Magazine in 1889 leading the company to remarkable growth before selling it to William Randolph Hearst in 1905; Walker also co-founded the Locomobile Company of America and later became a resident of Jefferson County, Colorado, where he donated forty acres outside of Denver to the Jesuits to build what is now Regis University. Cody wrote the article "Famous Hunting Parties on the Plains" for Cosmopolitan in June 1894.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to John H. Tait

msContents.p: 1 hand-written page, with affixed route card

div1.note:
Klopp & Bartlett Co. Omaha
The Henshaw Hotel
Absolutely Fireproof
European Plan
T. J. O' Brien, Proprietor. Omaha, Neb.1
LAMH UACHTAR LAIDIRAN
div1.p: Show notices to John Brisbin Walker. Dutton Fred Hutch and others.2

div1.note:
Winter Quarters and General Office-—Symes Building—Denver Colo.
Two Big Institutions Joined Together at One Price of Admission
Route Card Season 1915
The Sells-Floto Circus Buffalo—Bill's Original Wild West
No. 9

back.note: Note 1: This undated note was probably written before August 1915, based on the presence of the attached route card for the Sells-Floto Circus' scheduled performances in that month.

Note 2: John Brisben Walker (1847-1931) had a varied career in manufacturing, ranching, real estate speculation, and journalism. His ranching and real estate activities were centered around Denver, Colorado, from about 1879 to 1889; he then moved to New York. From 1889 to 1915 he owned Cosmopolitan magazine. In June 1894 the magazine published an article signed by Cody entitled "Famous Hunting Parties on the Plains." Walker sold Cosmopolitan to William Randolph Hearst in 1915 for a large profit. "Dutton" may refer to either Samuel F. Dutton (born c. 1869), who was then the proprietor of the Albany Hotel in Denver, or his younger brother Frank R. Dutton, who helped manage the hotel. The Dutton brothers were pallbearers at Cody's funeral in 1917. "Fred Hutch" is probably Frederick Bailey Hutchinson, nephew of the famous showman James A. Bailey (1847-1906). Hutchinson served as manager for Buffalo Bill's Wild West during its final European tour, 1902-1906.
